comment.author: 55198937@N05
comment._content: View today from Google Streetview - the terrace at the bottom of the street is the only recognisable building. The street was cut in two for the Harbour Bridge Approaches and houses renumbered: maps.google.com.au/maps?q=Burton+St,+Milsons+Point+New+So...

comment.author: 73199923@N00
comment._content: YOUNG WIFE SHOT DEAD. THE HUSBAND WOUNDED. Sydney, Wednesday 18 November 1914 Mrs. Gertrude Spratt (22) was fatally shot, and her husband, Charles Spratt (24), was wounded in Burton Street, North Sydney, last night. Mrs. Spratt, whose maiden name was Gertrude Ruth Cork, had been married, unknown to her relatives, to Spratt. For some time she lived with her sister, Mrs. Allen Spratt, lived in Geoffrey Street. Mrs. Spratt went to bed last night about 8 o'clock, and soon afterwards her husband (Spratt) called and went upstairs. A few minutes later three shots were heard. Mrs. Allen rushed upstairs and found Spratt and his wife lying on the landing. Mrs Spratt had a wound over the heart and another in the shoulder, while the man was bleeding from a wound in the head. Mrs. Allen called in the police, who took the couple to tho hospital. Mrs. Spratt died at 11 o'clock. Spratt's wound is not regarded as serious. trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/45304438?searchTerm=Burt...

comment.author: 55198937@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/hpeters] Charles Herbert Spratt was found guilty and sentenced to death .. but .. mercy recommended (due to extreme provocation - what else!). He apparently died in 1948 at Broken Hill. trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/92570979?searchTerm=char...

comment.author: 73199923@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/angeljim46] WIFE MURDER IN SYDNEY. SENTENCE OF DEATH PASSED.

At the Central Criminal Court Charles Herbert Splatt, aged 25, was place on trial on a charge of having murdered his wife, Selina Spratt at North Sydney on November 17 last The case for the Crown was to the effect that although they had been married since Match 17 1914, the accused and his wife had never lived together. He was a turner and fitter. His wife, who was formerly a Miss Cork, was employed at the Sydney Ferry Company's change box at Circular Quay. They met each other at the Quay

On the night of the tragedy he went to the house and shot his wife, afterwards turning the revolver on himself. On the day of the tragedy the wife had gone to a tramway picnic down the harbour despite a request from her husband that they should spend the day together. 

In his statement from the dock the accused declared that he loved his vvife dearly He did not know how he had come to shoot her 

The evidence for the defence showed that the accused had been greatly worried from the time of his marriage because the wedding had been kept strictly. There were frequent quarrels chiefly over the fact that his wife declared she would not he a wife to him, or give up her work and live with him 

The jury returned a verdict of guilty with a strong recommendation to mercy on account of extreme provocation.

Sentence of death was pronounced.
